content: First of all, I wanna say that although Amazon may have some date when they say it will be in stock or some date when they say itll be delivered, just know that it may be earlier than anticipated. I ordered mine thinking it wasnt gonna be here until  around June 4th, so about 3 weeks to a month after I ordered the switch, but fortunately, it came 2 weeks earlier! Apparently, Im far from the only one who has experienced this, and a number of people have gotten their switch earlier than expected, so dont look at the date thinking thats when youre gonna get it, cause you may just get a nice surprise like a number of customers did. Yes, there are some stock issues with the switch at the moment as well as some production issues, but they are not as bad as theyre made out to be, so if you are thinking about getting the switch, go ahead and pull the trigger! Also, DO NOT BUY FRON SCALPERS. As some other people have mentioned, they will buy a switch and then sell it for a greater price than needed in order to make a profit, and although it may be tempting to buy from them so you can get it sooner, it is so not worth paying the extra money when the situation is actually better than amazon makes it out to be. So much faulty hardware it's ridiculous. Shortly after purchasing you'll realize your joycons are broken, drifting to the side which ruins the gaming experience. And they will disconnect from the console as a whole which sucks as well especially if you're on an online game or a combat orientated game like BOTW and Splatoon. Leaving you a sitting duck ready to lose because you have to wait for your joycons to reconnect. Also, there is such an issue with the joycons as a whole there have been class action lawsuits against Nintendo because of them. My joycons don't even connect for handheld play anymore so my switch has become a stationary console, and then next to obliterate any chances of me enjoying my switch, that cost just as much as my quality controlled systems like my Xbox, the fan completely quit working which has reduced this console to a ticking time bomb of how long I can actually enjoy it before it auto shuts off unless I fork up the $80 to get it repaired. title: Worth it if you want it
content: The ability to swap from dock to handheld still amazes me to this day. The library of games is crazy good, The battery life isn't bad, and the build is fairly durable. The screen is prone to scratching due to it being plastic, but a $10 screen protector fixes that easily. The controllers do go bad over time. I would recommend also purchasing a pro controller due to it having a better feel for me personally and they last far longer than any Joycon I've had. This purchase date was for my sister but I've had mine since near release and have gone through 3 pairs of Joycon, meanwhile my oldest pro controller (between 4 or 5 years) of the 3 I currently have has only shown slight signs of degradation. There is a "Nintendo tax" on some games which basically means they cost more than they would on other consoles (e.g. Borderlands collection I got on pc for like $20 where as the switch is charging $50 for games released between 2009-2014 so that you can play them on graphically worse hardware, but the portable part may be worth it for some people with certain games). The online services are really bad a lot of the time especially when playing with people who are far away or have otherwise unstable connections. Playing with random people online can be a very painstaking process a lot of the time. With all this being said, I love this console. It is the only console I use (I also have a pc and a ps4). I only look at it so critically due to how much I love it. If I didn't spend hours and hours using this thing I wouldn't be telling you all it's flaws in a 4-star review. It can be frustrating sometimes, but the exclusives are amazing (there are also a lot of great 3rd party games but I mainly mean that BOTW is a masterpiece and Mario Odyssey is phenomenal) and the "home console and handheld" idea is honestly incredible. I basically wrote an essay about this thing to tell you how much I love it.

You can buy physical copies or digital copies of games and some are digital only through the eshop. This is a console that is great for all ages of people, young or old and when I'm tired of hack and slash on my PS4, the Switch has many chill titles of games to relax with. Microsoft and Sony are far superior systems as far as hardware and software goes. But is it the best console for nostalgia and simple yet addictive gaming that is guaranteed to make you flashback to a time when life was so much simpler? Absolutely. The fact that I can play at home or effortlessly take it with me is a major selling point. The other being a classic series of games (and the modern versions of them) that we grew up with. Zero buyers remorse. So whether you're from the nintendo generation like myself or you have kids (or no kids) I say if you've been thinking about buying a switch then just get one. Contacted Nintendo support and after some time-wasting, I'll need to send it in for a warranty repair. Should be without the device for over a month by current estimates. Another issue: Setting up the 37 accounts, email logins, user names, and other associated nicknames and logins is a ridiculous process. content: Sure, it's no PS4 or PS5, but it's an incredible little machine with such incredible versatility in such a tiny package. While it might not have the pure processing power and graphics capability of the other two major systems it does do what Nintendo has done best for a long time, provide a reasonably priced quality portable gaming system. The advantage this time is that the Switch is both a home console and a portable console in one unit. This is something that consoles in general have never really been able to do until now and it's amazing how great the game quality is even in this small form factor. I mean, the Wii was good in the motion control but the gimmick did wear after a bit. The WiiU really felt like a disappointment in that it just didn't bring much to the table and Nintendo clearly wasn't going to be able to compete in the home console market against the other two juggernauts. What Nintendo has always been great at though is dominating the portable gaming market and the switch sees them bringing their expertise in the portable market to the home console market in a power play that really paid off in my opinion. Now, this system does still suffer from some of Nintendo's generally less favorable business practices so do take that in to account. The price for the Switch itself actually isn't that unreasonable so I don't fault them for that whatsoever. The peripherals, on the other hand, really put a dent in the pocketbook if you need to buy anything that didn't come in the box (and you probably will need to at some point, let's be honest). The price of games also comes at a premium just as it has with past Nintendo systems as you will rarely see even older games every discounted or put on sale while such things are very common with the the competing systems. For instances, "Zelda: Link's Awakening", which has roughly 13 to 15 hours of content, will still cost you $60 which is incredibly high for a game that offers so little content with little replay value. Sadly Nintendo has a tendency of doing this and always has so do be prepared to pay premium prices for most games with the Switch. All in all I still think the unit is worth it particularly since you just can't find a better portable gaming platform than this. I definitely recommend getting the Switch over the Switch Lite as those are fully integrated and if you bust an analog stick or a button you're pretty much screwed. With a Switch you can replace the side controllers as you need and we all know controller buttons and analog sticks can wear over time so that alone is worth it. I mean, for $100 more you get a heck of a lot better of a system than you do with a lite so I highly recommend going this route if you're looking in to a Switch.

title: First Time Nintendo Switch User
content: As someone who's been playing on the PS4, the Nintendo Switch is a great change of pace. This is my ever handheld gaming device and I got to say, man is it impressive! For starters, the design of the switch is awesome, not too heavy or light. Every time you slip the joycons on the side of the switch, it makes a satisfying click sound. The dock is great for playing games on your TV or monitor (plus it looks clean too). After spending about 10 hours on the switch, I am satisfied with the joycons and feel no need to purchase the pro controller. Although the joycons are a bit small (perfect for kids), they will get the job done. Next, it is important that you take storage into consideration since the switch only comes with a base of 32 gb. I bought the SanDisk 128 gb card and that will be enough for me. If you plan on playing games like Mortal Kombat, I'd suggest upgrading to 200 and above, since those games take up more storage (ex. MK11 Aftermath is 30 gb). Depending on how much you play, battery life will vary. Of course, more labor-intensive games will drain the battery quicker. I only have two games on my switch so far (Attack on Titan and Fortnite) and those games tend to drain the battery significantly faster. I dont have any other games to compare to, but while playing AoT, the battery lasted about 4-5 hours before needing a charge. This is super impressive since AoT is an open-world style game with dozens of titans running around the map destroying buildings and such, but frames will drop from time to time if there too much going on at once. Even after playing for a long time, the switch is only some-what warm, which is great if you are playing in handheld mode. Lastly, I want to talk about the price point of the switch. The retail price is $299.99 and that's what I paid for when I bought the Mario Version. It's a steep price since it's alongside the price point of an Xbox or PS4, but it is worth it if you enjoy playing games on the go and love Nintendo titles such as Zelda and Mario. In addition to the retail price of the console, also take into account other expenses such as extra storage (I would only buy the ones from Nintendo, SanDisk, or Samsung), a screen protector (very important in my opinion. The first thing I did when I unboxed the switch was to put on a screen protector), extra controllers and/or joycons, and maybe Nintendo's online membership if you want to play online and with friends (games like Fortnite will not need a membership). All in all, the switch is a great device and I can't recommend it enough. It's a great console for families or if you just want to play alone.

title: An Amazing Little Console
content: The Nintendo Switch is a great gaming console for people new to gaming and veterans alike. Offering an extensive library of games for both kids and adults, its a device the whole family can enjoy. Its substantially more affordable than its competitors Microsofts Xbox One, and Sonys PlayStation 4. Produced by the well-known gaming giant Nintendo, a company with over 131 years of gaming entertainment under its belt, consumers can rest assured that they are making a quality purchase. The Switch is a hybrid gaming console released by Nintendo on March 3rd, 2017. Since its debut, it has received a significant hardware upgrade in addition to limited editions of the console. On September 20th, 2019, the Switch Lite was released nationwide. This version of the console lacks the hybrid functionality, giving up the ability to connect to a TV in favor of a lower price and a smaller, lighter form factor. The standard console is available at most retailers and online for $299 and the Lite for $199, though COVID 19 has seen these prices climb substantially higher. For this review, I will be focusing on the standard upgraded edition of the platform. The main appeal of a hybrid console is that it can be used in two configurations: handheld mode for portable play, or placed into its dock allowing the device to stream to a TV. The small controllers, called Joy-Cons, slide into slots on the sides when in handheld mode. They can also be removed and used as two separate controllers, saving parents $80 on a second controller for multiplayer situations when docked. The new revision includes a more power-efficient CPU, the brain of the console, and a brighter, more vibrant screen. Upgrading the CPU has led to a 30 percent increase in efficiency, meaning more gaming time when away from a power source. The old battery is reported to last 2.5-6.5 hours and the new one 4.5 to 9 hours, depending on the game and how high the brightness of the screen is set. In terms of software, the Switch offers an extensive library, a must for any gaming console. Without ample software to support the platform, the audience may quickly run out of games to play or things to do; this is not the case with the Switch. The library of games available for purchase can be accessed through the built-in eShop. These games can be downloaded to an SD card inserted into the system. Games can also be purchased physically in a cartridge format for those who would prefer the longevity of owning their library physically. The collection of games offered is vast and ranges from family-friendly titles such as Mario, Zelda, and Donkey Kong; to more adult titles such as Doom, Skyrim, and Wolfenstein: The New Colossus. The support for this system is incredible, primarily due to the fact that the install base is so large. The surge in sales has given incentive to developers and publishers to create more content, something which cannot be said about the previous Nintendo console, the Nintendo Wii U. Even after being on the market for more than three years, the substantial library of games shows no sign of this growth slowing down. At purchase straight out of the box, you get: The main console, two Joy-Cons, the Joy-Con grip accessory, two wrist straps for the controllers, the dock, an AC power adapter, and an HDMI cable. SD cards, games, and Nintendo Online must be purchased separately. Consumers wishing to use the online services can buy a membership for $3.99 a month, $7.99 for three months, or $19.99 for a year. A family plan is also offered at $34.99 a year and covers up to eight consoles. Members gain access to exclusive game titles, Super Mario Brothers 35 and Tetris 99. Membership also includes over seventy NES and Super NES titles. Additionally, Nintendo will allow players to back up thei game saves to the cloud, easing fears of ever losing game progress. What is lacking, however, is any real social aspect to the online community. Without voice chat, a means to message your friends, or in-game achievements, the platform falls short, in this regard, compared to its competitors. Customers have voiced complaints on this matter for years, only to be ignored. Another negative to be aware of is the issue of Joy-Con drift. Over time the thumbsticks are known to wear out, and games will register input when there is no action being performed by the player. Nintendo has vehemently fought against claims that this is an issue, even to the point of being taken to court by many parties in the form of class-action lawsuits. Drift is a reasonably widespread phenomenon and cannot be overstated; the likelihood that you will experience issues with the longevity of your Joy-Cons is high. This may or may not be a concern, as Nintendo offers to replace controllers that experience this. If you have issues with faulty controllers, youll likely need to purchase additional ones. The controllers can be bought separately from the console for $80 for use until Nintendo gets around to repairing the ones you already own. In conclusion, I still highly recommend this system despite its shortcomings. The hours I have spent enjoying a vast collection of exciting, engaging titles on it have far outweighed any frustration I have experienced with the controllers' durability or the lackluster online experience. The ability to take your game from the living room to on the go and back again is a real treat. If youre a busy person looking for an affordable console, this is sure to meet your needs.
